description: This course examines the complex and shifting relationship between human and non-human
animals in the ancient Roman world. Through literary sources and artistic evidence, students
explore the Roman view of animals and their use of them for food, entertainment, and
companionship. The class discusses Roman attitudes toward the non-human animal "other"
and the ethical implications of such attitudes, both in antiquity and today. All selections from
Greek and Latin literature are read in English translation. Counts toward ancient studies, classics,
Greek, and Latin majors. Offered during Interim.
